   tomorrow, q1H neuro checks, continue propofol which is somewhat
   protective for seizures, repeat LP with opening pressure, MRI head w/
   and w/o contrast (ordered).
   .
   -Had increased pupil size 3h after 1st CT head. CT head repeated at
   1400. No change from prior. Per Radiology and ID - recommend MRI head.
   .
   -Pt was HIV negative as of 2 years ago - required to get green card
   from Kenyan embassy. Her 17mo baby is HIV negative (unsure if she was
   tested at pregnancy).
   .
   -Updated contact info: [**Name (NI) 8501**] [**Name (NI) 8522**] (cousin/brother, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8508**]

   [**Doctor First Name **] - Charge Nurse/Boss at her work: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8526**]
   .
   -Plasmapheresis: catheter placed by IR, performed [**7-14**]
   -ET tube cuff didn't deflate when repositioning; anesthesia
   re-intubated
   .
   -Faxed order for HSV PCR on CSF on [**2184-7-14**] - will take 3-5 days to
   return as it is a sendout. Fax: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8527**] (attn: Lab); Lab main
   phone number [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8528**] (main lab) - call and cancel as we sent our
   own.
   -Medical records: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8529**]; they sent ER records from [**2184-7-13**]. They
   did not send her prior visits for malaria treatment - requested [**2184-7-14**]
   at 1630.

   bruising (may also partially explain her Hct drop)
   .

   MRSA pending
   .
   [**2184-7-15**] CXR pending
   .
   [**7-14**] CT head 1:
   There is no evidence of acute hemorrhage, edema, mass effect or
   infarction. The [**Doctor Last Name 1359**]-white matter differentiation is preserved. The
   ventricles are normal in size and appearance. There is a large right
   maxillary mucus-retention cyst; otherwise, the visualized paranasal
   sinuses
   and mastoid air cells are unremarkable. No osseous abnormality is
   identified.
   IMPRESSION: No evidence of cerebral edema or other finding to suggest
   cerebral malaria on this unenhanced CT examination.
   .
   [**7-14**] CT head 2:
   No acute intracranial abnormality. No specific evidence for
   cerebral edema on this examination. MRI may be more sensitive for acute
   changes if clinical concern remains
   Assessment and Plan
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 MALARIA
   .
   Assessment and Plan:
   This 24F with recent falciparum malaria is evaluated for altered mental
   status.
   .
   * Altered mental status, suspected cerebral malaria - Patient had
   questionable seizure and remains altered. She does not have a known
   seizure disorder. Current confusional state may reflect post-ictal
   status or, less likely, nonconvulsive status. I am most concerned for
   an underlying CNS infection.
   .
   Bacterial meningitis seems less likely in the face of an unremarkable
   CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose. Her elevated CSF RBC count raises
   the question of herpes encephalitis - however would expect elevated
   protein with CNS herpes; suspect RBCs are [**12-22**] to traumatic OSH spinal
   tap.
   .
   She is not known to be HIV positive - though this needs to be
   clarified.
   .
   Among other noninfectious causes of her confusion, consider also toxic
   ingestion though less likely with her negative tox screens. Her basic
   metabolic panel here is notable only for mild hyperglycemia and an
   anion gap (see below). Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass
   lesion to account for her symptoms.
   .
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Empiric IV quinidine. Consider discussing with CDC regarding
   artemesinin availability.
   - Will continue acyclovir for now pending HSV PCR though think less
   likely
   - Continue ceftriaxone 2g daily given increased risk of GNR infection
   in this setting
   - Continuous EKG monitoring while on quinidine
   - Follow fingerstick q4h
   - Follow parasite smears daily
   - Given concern for CNS malaria will discuss exchange transfusion with
   bloodbank
   - HIV
   - EEG
   - Add on Ca/Mag/Phos
   - Consider MRI head
   - Seizure precautions
   - ID recommendations appreciated
   - Consider neurology consult
   .
   * Fever
   Fevers are most likely due to malaria, as above. Other considerations
   includ aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia given her altered mental
   status; however her CXR does not show any infiltrate. She has mild
   pyuria on her UA - ?whether her reported right flank pain may have been
   [**12-22**] pyelonephritis. No diarrhea or abdominal tenderness worrisome for
   an infectious GI process.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Continuing ceftriaxone as above
   - Follow up pending blood cultures, add on urine culture
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
   .
   * Gap acidosis
   Malaria could cause acidosis. [**Month (only) 8**] be due to starvation ketosis given
   urine ketones. Not hyperglycemic to suggest DKA. Lactate is within
   normal limits. Ingestion a consideration but less likely with negative
   urine and serum tox screens.
   - Repeat electrolytes
   - Add on Osms
   - Check ABG
   .
   * Anemia
   Baseline Hct uncertain. With question of malaria hemolysis is obviously
   a concern - however patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
   No report of bleeding. INR only minimally elevated - think DIC is less
   likely.
   - Add on haptoglobin/LDH, fibrinogen, check peripheral smear
   - Follow CBC and coags [**Hospital1 **], maintain T+S, transfuse Hct>25
   .
   * Domestic abuse
   - Social work consult
   - Screen visitors
   .
   FEN NPO given altered MS
   Access PIV x2, ?pheresis catheter pending exchange transfusion plans
   PPX pneumoboots, PPI
   Dispo ICU
   Code presumed full
   Comm: [**Name (NI) 8501**] [**Name (NI) 8522**] (cousin/brother, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8508**] (cell); [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8523**]
   (house)) [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 77**] [**Doctor First Name 866**] safe to call him, [**Doctor First Name 866**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8507**] (friend)
   -Do not let in [**Doctor Last Name **] Tah (ex-boyfriend)
   ICU [**Name (NI) 151**]
   Nutrition: NPO
   Glycemic Control:  monitoring

   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer:  famotidine
   VAP:  bundle

   Communication:  Comments: [**Name (NI) 8501**] [**Name (NI) 8522**] (cousin/brother, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8508**]

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of falciparum malaria. She has a history of recent travel to Kenya, where she contracted the disease. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. She has a fever of 101.9°F and is experiencing altered mental status, which is suspected to be due to cerebral malaria.

The patient's laboratory results show a WBC count of 10.7, Hct of 24.1, and a parasite smear that is positive for P. falciparum. Her CSF analysis shows an opening pressure of 220 mm H2O, with 25 mg/dL of protein, 87 mg/dL of glucose, and 2 WBCs.

The patient is receiving empiric treatment for malaria with quinidine, and her condition is being monitored closely. She is also receiving anticonvulsant medication to manage her altered mental status.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cerebral edema: The patient's altered mental status and fever may be indicative of cerebral edema, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and fever may also be indicative of seizures, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to hypoxia and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and fever may be indicative of an underlying infection, which can lead to sepsis and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric treatment for malaria with quinidine.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and respiratory function closely.
3. Consider adding anticonvulsant medication to manage the patient's altered mental status.
4. Monitor the patient's laboratory results, including WBC count, Hct, and parasite smear, to ensure that the treatment is effective.
5. Consider consulting with a neurologist or infectious disease specialist to manage the patient's altered mental status and potential infection.
6. Consider performing a lumbar puncture to rule out meningitis or encephalitis.
7. Consider ordering an MRI or CT scan to rule out cerebral edema or other intracranial abnormalities.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, fever, and respiratory failure. She has a history of falciparum malaria and was recently treated for it. However, she continues to experience altered mental status, which is suspected to be due to cerebral malaria. She was intubated for airway protection and received plasma exchange transfusion to decrease parasitemia. She has also received quinidine, acyclovir, and ceftriaxone.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 10.7-16.3 K/uL
* Hct: 24.1-28.1%
* Plt: 497-320
* Cr: 0.6 mg/dL
* TCO2: 22 mm Hg
* Glucose: 121-167 mg/dL
* CSF: Opening pressure 220 mm H2O, protein 25 mg/dL, glucose 87 mg/dL, WBC 2, RBC 1, poly 76, lymph 18, mono 6, EOs 0

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Sclera anicteric, MMM, pupils asymmetric with L larger than R
* Neck supple
* Pulm: Lungs clear bilaterally, no rales or wheezing
* CV: Regular S1 S2 no m/r/g
* Abd: Soft nontender, +bowel sounds, no organomegaly or mass
* Extrem: Warm, palpable pulses
* Neuro: No posturing, makes purposeful movements with noxious stimuli
* Derm: No rash or jaundice, toes downgoing bilaterally, no clonus

Potential medical complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status is suspected to be due to cerebral malaria. If left untreated, this can lead to severe complications such as seizures, coma, and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever and altered mental status may be indicative of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure if not treated promptly.
4. Hemolysis: The patient's anemia and elevated LDH may indicate hemolysis, which can lead to severe complications such as kidney failure and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
5. DIC: The patient's elevated INR and decreased platelet count may indicate DIC, which can lead to bleeding and organ failure.
6. HIV infection: The patient's unknown HIV status and history of falciparum malaria may increase her risk of HIV infection.
7. Meningitis: The patient's CSF analysis shows an opening pressure of 220 mm H2O, which may indicate meningitis. If left untreated, this can lead to severe complications such as brain damage and death.
8. UTI: The patient's pyuria and mild pyelonephritis may indicate a UTI, which can lead to severe complications such as sepsis and kidney failure.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue monitoring her closely and managing her respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status. It is also crucial to investigate the cause of her altered mental status and treat any underlying infections or complications promptly.

   Assessment and Plan:
   This 24F with recent falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental
   status.
   .
   * Altered mental status
 Pt continues to be unresponsive, even when
   off propofol. Currently, suspected cerebral malaria as pt has h/o P.
   falciparum malaria.  Patient had questionable seizure and remains
   altered. She does not have a known seizure disorder. Current
   confusional state may reflect post-ictal status or, less likely,
   nonconvulsive status. I am most concerned for an underlying CNS
   infection.
   .
   Bacterial meningitis seems less likely in the face of an unremarkable
   CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose. Her elevated CSF RBC count raises
   the question of herpes encephalitis - however would expect elevated
   protein with CNS herpes; suspect RBCs are [**12-22**] to traumatic OSH spinal
   tap.
   .
   She is not known to be HIV positive - though this needs to be
   clarified.
   .
   Among other noninfectious causes of her confusion, consider also toxic
   ingestion though less likely with her negative tox screens. Her basic
   metabolic panel here is notable only for mild hyperglycemia and an
   anion gap (see below). Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass
   lesion to account for her symptoms.
   .
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Empiric IV quinidine. Consider discussing with CDC regarding
   artemesinin availability.
   - Will continue acyclovir for now pending HSV PCR though think less
   likely
   - Continue ceftriaxone 2g daily given increased risk of GNR infection
   in this setting
   - Continuous EKG monitoring while on quinidine
   - Follow fingerstick q4h
   - Follow parasite smears daily
   - Given concern for CNS malaria will discuss exchange transfusion with
   bloodbank
   - HIV
   - EEG
   - Add on Ca/Mag/Phos
   - Consider MRI head
   - Seizure precautions
   - ID recommendations appreciated
   - Consider neurology consult
   .
   * Fever
   Fevers are most likely due to malaria, as above. Other considerations
   includ aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia given her altered mental
   status; however her CXR does not show any infiltrate. She has mild
   pyuria on her UA - ?whether her reported right flank pain may have been
   [**12-22**] pyelonephritis. No diarrhea or abdominal tenderness worrisome for
   an infectious GI process.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Continuing ceftriaxone as above
   - Follow up pending blood cultures, add on urine culture
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
   .
   * Gap acidosis
   Malaria could cause acidosis. [**Month (only) 8**] be due to starvation ketosis given
   urine ketones. Not hyperglycemic to suggest DKA. Lactate is within
   normal limits. Ingestion a consideration but less likely with negative
   urine and serum tox screens.
   - Repeat electrolytes
   - Add on Osms
   - Check ABG
   .
   * Anemia
   Baseline Hct uncertain. With question of malaria hemolysis is obviously
   a concern - however patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
   No report of bleeding. INR only minimally elevated - think DIC is less
   likely.
   - Add on haptoglobin/LDH, fibrinogen, check peripheral smear
   - Follow CBC and coags [**Hospital1 **], maintain T+S, transfuse Hct>25
   .
   * Domestic abuse
   - Social work consult
   - Screen visitors
   .
   FEN NPO given altered MS
   Access PIV x2, ?pheresis catheter pending exchange transfusion plans
   PPX pneumoboots, PPI
   Dispo ICU

   and mastoid air cells are unremarkable. No osseous abnormality is
   identified.
   IMPRESSION: No evidence of cerebral edema or other finding to suggest
   cerebral malaria on this unenhanced CT examination.
   .
   [**7-14**] CT head 2:
   No acute intracranial abnormality. No specific evidence for
   cerebral edema on this examination. MRI may be more sensitive for acute
   changes if clinical concern remains
   Assessment and Plan
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 MALARIA

   Assessment and Plan:
   This 24F with recent falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental
   status.
   .
   * Altered mental status
 Pt continues to be unresponsive, even when
   off propofol. Currently, suspected cerebral malaria as pt has h/o P.
   falciparum malaria.  Patient had questionable seizure and remains
   altered. She does not have a known seizure disorder. Current
   confusional state may reflect post-ictal status or, less likely,
   nonconvulsive status. I am most concerned for an underlying CNS
   infection.
   .
   Bacterial meningitis seems less likely in the face of an unremarkable
   CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose. Her elevated CSF RBC count raises
   the question of herpes encephalitis - however would expect elevated
   protein with CNS herpes; suspect RBCs are [**12-22**] to traumatic OSH spinal
   tap.
   .
   She is not known to be HIV positive - though this needs to be
   clarified.
   .
   Among other noninfectious causes of her confusion, consider also toxic
   ingestion though less likely with her negative tox screens. Her basic
   metabolic panel here is notable only for mild hyperglycemia and an
   anion gap (see below). Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass
   lesion to account for her symptoms.
   .
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Empiric IV quinidine. Consider discussing with CDC regarding
   artemesinin availability.
   - Will continue acyclovir for now pending HSV PCR though think less
   likely
   - Continue ceftriaxone 2g daily given increased risk of GNR infection
   in this setting
   - Continuous EKG monitoring while on quinidine
   - Follow fingerstick q4h
   - Follow parasite smears daily
   - Given concern for CNS malaria will discuss exchange transfusion with
   bloodbank
   - HIV
   - EEG
   - Add on Ca/Mag/Phos
   - Consider MRI head
   - Seizure precautions
   - ID recommendations appreciated
   - Consider neurology consult
   .
   * Fever
   Fevers are most likely due to malaria, as above. Other considerations
   includ aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia given her altered mental
   status; however her CXR does not show any infiltrate. She has mild
   pyuria on her UA - ?whether her reported right flank pain may have been
   [**12-22**] pyelonephritis. No diarrhea or abdominal tenderness worrisome for
   an infectious GI process.
   - Malaria empiric treatment as above
   - Continuing ceftriaxone as above
   - Follow up pending blood cultures, add on urine culture
   - Call OSH for pending micro results
   - Obtain further records regarding treatment and workup from [**Hospital1 958**]
   .
   * Gap acidosis
   Malaria could cause acidosis. [**Month (only) 8**] be due to starvation ketosis given
   urine ketones. Not hyperglycemic to suggest DKA. Lactate is within
   normal limits. Ingestion a consideration but less likely with negative
   urine and serum tox screens.
   - Repeat electrolytes
   - Add on Osms
   - Check ABG
   .
   * Anemia
   Baseline Hct uncertain. With question of malaria hemolysis is obviously
   a concern - however patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
   No report of bleeding. INR only minimally elevated - think DIC is less
   likely.
   - Add on haptoglobin/LDH, fibrinogen, check peripheral smear
   - Follow CBC and coags [**Hospital1 **], maintain T+S, transfuse Hct>25
   .
   * Domestic abuse
   - Social work consult
   - Screen visitors
   .
   FEN NPO given altered MS
   Access PIV x2, ?pheresis catheter pending exchange transfusion plans
   PPX pneumoboots, PPI
   Dispo ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, fever, and seizures. She has a history of falciparum malaria and was found unresponsive and unclothed. She was intubated for airway protection and started on empiric IV quinidine. The patient has a number of laboratory abnormalities, including an elevated white blood cell count, increased lactate, and anion gap acidosis. She also has a parasitic infection, as evidenced by the presence of Plasmodium falciparum in her blood.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizures are consistent with cerebral malaria, a severe complication of falciparum malaria.
2. Bacterial meningitis: Although the patient's CSF wbc count, protein, and glucose are unremarkable, bacterial meningitis is still a possibility, especially given the patient's history of malaria.
3. Herpes encephalitis: The patient's elevated CSF RBC count and mild hyperglycemia raise the question of herpes encephalitis, although this is less likely given the patient's negative HSV PCR.
4. Toxic ingestion: Although the patient's toxic screens are negative, toxic ingestion is still a possibility, especially given the patient's altered mental status.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to malaria hemolysis, although the patient's total bilirubin is within normal limits.
6. Gap acidosis: The patient's anion gap acidosis is likely due to malaria, although the patient's lactate is within normal limits.
7. Domestic abuse: The patient's altered mental status and lack of recollection of events raise the possibility of domestic abuse.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric IV quinidine for cerebral malaria.
2. Consider discussing with CDC regarding artemesinin availability.
3. Continue acyclovir for herpes encephalitis, although this is less likely.
4. Continue ceftriaxone for bacterial meningitis, although this is less likely.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolytes and follow up pending blood cultures.
6. Consider a neurology consult to evaluate the patient's altered mental status.
7. Consider a social work consult to evaluate the patient's domestic situation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male from Country 1773 with a diagnosis of probable CNS Malaria, intubated for respiratory failure, and altered mental status.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with mechanical ventilation in place to protect his airway. His ABG results indicate a pH of 7.44, which is within the normal range. However, his PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 250 suggests that he may be at risk for developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's mental status is also critical, with concerns for ingestion, overdose, seizure, CNS infection, acute stroke syndrome, or malaria with CNS involvement. His initial CT scan suggests sulci effacement, although the quality of the scan is poor. A follow-up head CT was unrevealing, and an EEG is pending. The patient's EEG and CSF cultures will help guide further management.

The patient's laboratory results indicate anemia, which is attributed in part to malaria. His blood glucose levels are elevated, and he is at risk for developing hyperglycemia. His electrolyte levels are within normal range, but his magnesium levels are slightly elevated.

The patient's fluid status is hypovolemic, and he is at risk for developing hypovolemic shock. His nutritional support is inadequate, and he requires initiation of total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

The patient's medical history is significant for probable CNS Malaria, which carries a high mortality rate. He is receiving empiric IV quinidine and may require additional antimalarial therapy. He is also at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias and electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU. His total time spent in the ICU is 45 minutes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for developing ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and fever suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
3. Malaria: The patient's diagnosis of probable CNS Malaria carries a high mortality rate, and he is at risk for developing severe complications, including cerebral edema and seizures.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is attributed in part to malaria, and he is at risk for developing further anemia, which can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to his tissues.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's elevated blood glucose levels put him at risk for developing hyperglycemia, which can lead to further complications, including ketoacidosis and non-ketotic hyperglycemic coma.
6. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range, but he is at risk for developing electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's empiric IV quinidine therapy carries a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which can lead to cardiac arrest.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, intubated for airway protection, and mechanically ventilated. He has a history of probable CNS Malaria, which is likely causing his altered mental status. He is also experiencing fever, anemia, and hypovolemic fluid status. He has undergone various medical interventions, including initiation of quinidine therapy, and is being monitored for glucose and magnesium levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration. Close monitoring of ABG and ventilator settings is essential.
2. Malaria complications: The patient is at risk of developing complications from malaria, including cerebral malaria, seizures, and organ failure. Close monitoring of parasite levels and glucose levels is essential.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing secondary infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis. Close monitoring of cultures and antibiotic therapy is essential.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications, including cardiovascular instability and organ failure. Close monitoring of hemoglobin levels and transfusion requirements is essential.
5. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid status is hypovolemic, and there is a risk of further imbalance. Close monitoring of I/O and fluid management is essential.
6. Nutritional support: The patient requires nutritional support, and there is a risk of malnutrition if not properly managed. Close monitoring of nutritional intake and glucose levels is essential.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to further neurological complications, including seizures, status epilepticus, and cerebral edema. Close monitoring of neurological status and EEG is essential.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is at risk of deterioration, particularly with the presence of anemia and hypovolemic fluid status. Close monitoring of cardiovascular parameters, including blood pressure and cardiac rhythm, is essential.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust tube position as necessary.
2. Monitor ABG and ventilator settings closely.
3. Continue quinidine therapy and monitor parasite levels and glucose levels.
4. Monitor cultures and antibiotic therapy closely.
5. Provide nutritional support and monitor glucose levels.
6. Monitor I/O and fluid management closely.
7. Monitor neurological status and EEG closely.
8. Monitor cardiovascular parameters, including blood pressure and cardiac rhythm, closely.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She was intubated yesterday for airway protection and received plasma exchange transfusion to decrease parasitemia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.7°F)
* Heart rate: 79 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/67 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Head CT shows no evidence of bleed or mass lesion to account for her symptoms.

The patient has received the following medications:

* Propofol: 20 mcg/Kg/min
* Quinidine: 2g daily
* Acyclovir: 1g daily
* Ceftriaxone: 2g daily
* Famotidine: 1g daily

The patient has the following laboratory results:

* Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 497 x 10^9/L
* White blood cell count: 10.7 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 121 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* LDH: 206 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.1 mg/dL

The patient has the following potential medical complications:

* Cerebral malaria
* Seizures
* Meningitis
* Pneumonia
* Pyelonephritis
* Hemolysis
* Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
* Hypoglycemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hypophosphatemia

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing IV quinidine and monitoring for side effects
* Performing a head MRI today
* Following up on pending CSF studies, blood and urine cultures
* Obtaining further records regarding prior malaria treatment and workup
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and meningitis
* Following up on laboratory results, including CBC, coags, and blood cultures
* Continuing prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Providing seizure precautions and monitoring for seizure activity
* Following up on the patient's HIV status once she is able to give consent.

The patient's current status is critical, and she requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

**Medical History**: The patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status.

**Current Status**: The patient is intubated for airway protection, but is now following commands. She has a fever, mild pyuria, and anemia. Her lab results show elevated bilirubin and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

**Assessment and Plan**: The patient is suspected to have cerebral malaria, but other causes must be considered. She received plasma exchange transfusion on admission to decrease parasitemia. She is currently receiving IV quinidine, acyclovir, and ceftriaxone. She will be extubated today.

**Potential Complications**:

1. **Seizure**: The patient had a questionable seizure, and her altered mental status may reflect post-ictal status or nonconvulsive status.
2. **Meningitis**: The patient's CSF cultures are pending, and she received ceftriaxone to cover for possible meningitis.
3. **Pyelonephritis**: The patient has mild pyuria, and her right flank pain may be due to pyelonephritis.
4. **Anemia**: The patient's anemia may be due to hemolysis, and her elevated bilirubin levels support this diagnosis.
5. **DIC**: The patient's INR is only minimally elevated, making DIC less likely.
6. **Infectious GI process**: The patient has no diarrhea or abdominal tenderness, but her lab results show elevated LDH levels, which may indicate an infectious GI process.

**Monitoring and Follow-up**:

1. **Lab results**: Monitor CBC, coags, and liver function tests to assess the patient's anemia and potential liver damage.
2. **Parasite smears**: Follow up on parasite smears to monitor the patient's parasitemia.
3. **HIV status**: Obtain the patient's HIV status once she is able to give consent.
4. **MRI and EEG results**: Follow up on the patient's MRI and EEG results to assess for potential neurological damage.
5. **Seizure precautions**: Continue seizure precautions to prevent further seizures.
6. **Extubation**: Plan to extubate the patient today.
7. **Nutrition**: Continue TPN and advance as tolerated after extubation.
8. **Glycemic control**: Monitor glycemic control to prevent hypoglycemia.
9. **Lines**: Monitor the patient's lines for potential complications.
10. **Prophylaxis**: Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yof from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated predominately for airway protection.
   No evidence for active  pulmonary disease.  Good progress.  Plan to
   move to extubation trial.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS -- Much improved.  Attributed to cerebral
   malaria.  Initially found down, and unresponsive in the field.  Unclear
   duration.  Concerns include ingestion/OD, seizure with postictal state
   or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than
   meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, malaria with CNS involvement (i.e.
   cerebral malaria).  No signs suicide attempt.  Doubt cardiac event.
   Initial CT scan (outside hosptial) suggests sulci effacement, although
   poor quality scan.  Head CT unrevealing.  EEG (possible continuous),
   follow up CSF cultures (check for HSV), maintain mechanical
   ventilation.  MRI of head unrevealing.
   MALARIA -- Falciparum.  High mortality rate on appropriate therapy.
   Quinidine Rx.  Follow parasite peripheral blood smears.  Monitor
   glucose, monitor Mg.  Transfusion Medicine consultation in progress.
   ID consultation in progress.  Empiric IV quinidine, consider
   artemesinin (available through CDC).  Monitor ECG, glucose.
   FEVER -- attributed to malaria.  Maintain concerns for other sources,
   related to malaria or other complicating infections.  Monitor cultures.
   ANEMIA -- attributed in part to malaria.
   FLUIDS -- hypovolemic.  Monitor I/O.  Now with PICC and central access
   (via phoresis catheter).
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- hold TF pending extubation trial.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yof from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated predominately for airway protection.
   No evidence for active  pulmonary disease.  Good progress.  Plan to
   move to extubation trial.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS -- Much improved.  Attributed to cerebral
   malaria.  Initially found down, and unresponsive in the field.  Unclear
   duration.  Concerns include ingestion/OD, seizure with postictal state
   or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than
   meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, malaria with CNS involvement (i.e.
   cerebral malaria).  No signs suicide attempt.  Doubt cardiac event.
   Initial CT scan (outside hosptial) suggests sulci effacement, although
   poor quality scan.  Head CT unrevealing.  EEG (possible continuous),
   follow up CSF cultures (check for HSV), maintain mechanical
   ventilation.  MRI of head unrevealing.
   MALARIA -- Falciparum.  High mortality rate on appropriate therapy.
   Quinidine Rx.  Follow parasite peripheral blood smears.  Monitor
   glucose, monitor Mg.  Transfusion Medicine consultation in progress.
   ID consultation in progress.  Empiric IV quinidine, consider
   artemesinin (available through CDC).  Monitor ECG, glucose.
   FEVER -- attributed to malaria.  Maintain concerns for other sources,
   related to malaria or other complicating infections.  Monitor cultures.
   ANEMIA -- attributed in part to malaria.
   FLUIDS -- hypovolemic.  Monitor I/O.  Now with PICC and central access
   (via phoresis catheter).
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- hold TF pending extubation trial.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male with probable CNS Malaria, intubated for respiratory failure and altered mental status. The patient is making clinical improvement, with neurological improvement, and is now attending and following simple commands.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F), heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 111/68 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 100% on 30% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 10.7-16.3 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 24.1-28.1%
* Plt: 497-320 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 0.5-0.6 mg/dL
* TCO2: 22-26 mmHg
* Glucose: 121-167 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.8/24.9/1.2, ALT/AST: 13/13 IU/L, Alk Phos/TBili: 55/3.0 IU/L, Lactic Acid: 0.8 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.7 g/dL, LDH: 206 IU/L, Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL, PO4: 3.1 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Quinidine for malaria
* PPI for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* HOB elevation and mouth care for VAP prophylaxis

The patient's plan includes:

* Extubation trial
* Monitoring of glucose and Mg levels
* Follow-up CSF cultures and EEG
* Transfusion Medicine and ID consultations
* Empiric IV quinidine and consideration of artemesinin
* Monitoring of ECG and glucose levels

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Altered mental status
* Malaria-related complications, such as cerebral edema, seizures, or status epilepticus
* Anemia
* Fluid overload
* Nutritional deficiencies
* Infections, such as pneumonia, sepsis, or central line-associated bloodstream infections
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest
* Neurological complications, such as stroke or encephalitis

The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is ICU. The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   24 yof from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated predominately for airway protection.

   or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than
   meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, malaria with CNS involvement (i.e.
   cerebral malaria).  No signs suicide attempt.  Doubt cardiac event.
   Initial CT scan (outside hosptial) suggests sulci effacement, although

   artemesinin (available through CDC).  Monitor ECG, glucose.

   related to malaria or other complicating infections.  Monitor cultures.
   ANEMIA -- attributed in part to malaria.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to airway protection. The patient has made significant clinical improvement, with improved neurological status, attending, and following simple commands.

The patient has a history of probable CNS Malaria, which is attributed to his altered mental status. He was initially found down and unresponsive in the field, and his initial CT scan suggested sulci effacement, although the quality of the scan was poor. The patient has been treated with quinidine and is being monitored for parasite peripheral blood smears, glucose, and magnesium levels.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and there is a risk of respiratory failure if the ventilation is not properly managed.
2. Malaria: The patient has a high mortality rate due to malaria, and there is a risk of complications such as seizures, coma, and death if not properly treated.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which can lead to complications such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output.
4. Fluid imbalance: The patient has a hypovolemic state, which can lead to complications such as hypotension, tachycardia, and decreased organ perfusion.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) without lipids, which can lead to deficiencies in essential fatty acids and other nutrients.
6. Seizures: The patient has had a seizure, and there is a risk of recurrent seizures if not properly managed.
7. Infection: The patient has a risk of developing infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections, particularly with the use of central lines and catheters.
8. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient has had electrolyte imbalances, including hypomagnesemia, which can lead to complications such as muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill with multiple potential medical complications. Close monitoring and management of his condition are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 yof from [**Country 1773**] with probable CNS Malaria
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated predominately for airway protection.
   No evidence for active  pulmonary disease.  Good progress.  Plan to
   move to extubation trial.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS -- Much improved.  Attributed to cerebral
   malaria.  Initially found down, and unresponsive in the field.  Unclear
   duration.  Concerns include ingestion/OD, seizure with postictal state
   or status epilepticus, CNS infection (encephalitis rather than
   meningitis), acute stroke syndrome, malaria with CNS involvement (i.e.
   cerebral malaria).  No signs suicide attempt.  Doubt cardiac event.
   Initial CT scan (outside hosptial) suggests sulci effacement, although
   poor quality scan.  Head CT unrevealing.  EEG (possible continuous),
   follow up CSF cultures (check for HSV), maintain mechanical
   ventilation.  MRI of head unrevealing.
   MALARIA -- Falciparum.  High mortality rate on appropriate therapy.
   Quinidine Rx.  Follow parasite peripheral blood smears.  Monitor
   glucose, monitor Mg.  Transfusion Medicine consultation in progress.
   ID consultation in progress.  Empiric IV quinidine, consider
   artemesinin (available through CDC).  Monitor ECG, glucose.
   FEVER -- attributed to malaria.  Maintain concerns for other sources,
   related to malaria or other complicating infections.  Monitor cultures.
   ANEMIA -- attributed in part to malaria.
   FLUIDS -- hypovolemic.  Monitor I/O.  Now with PICC and central access
   (via phoresis catheter).

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and probable CNS Malaria. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and his neurological status has improved significantly, with him now following simple commands.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and abnormal liver function tests. His blood chemistry results indicate hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia. His coagulation profile shows an elevated international normalized ratio (INR) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT).

The patient's medical history is significant for probable CNS Malaria, which is attributed to the patient's travel to a country with a high incidence of malaria. The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with cerebral malaria, with symptoms of altered mental status, seizures, and respiratory failure.

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%.

The patient's physical examination is significant for a normal temperature, blood pressure, and heart rate. His respiratory examination shows clear lung fields, and his neurological examination shows an altered mental status with no focal deficits.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated lactic acid level, which may indicate inadequate tissue perfusion. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.

The patient's medical treatment includes empiric therapy for malaria with quinidine, and he is being monitored for glucose and magnesium levels. He is also receiving transfusions and has a PICC line and pheresis catheter in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration. Close monitoring of his respiratory status is necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is improving, but he is still at risk for further neurological deterioration. Monitoring of his neurological status and treatment of any neurological complications are necessary.
3. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and the presence of a central line make him at risk for infection. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of infection.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's coagulopathy and the presence of a central line make him at risk for bleeding complications. Close monitoring of his bleeding status and treatment of any bleeding complications are necessary.
5. Renal failure: The patient's electrolyte abnormalities and the presence of a central line make him at risk for renal failure. Close monitoring of his renal function and treatment of any renal complications are necessary.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is normal, but he is at risk for cardiac complications due to his critical illness. Close monitoring of his cardiac status and treatment of any cardiac complications are necessary.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status is normal, but he is at risk for gastrointestinal complications due to his critical illness. Close monitoring of his gastrointestinal status and treatment of any gastrointestinal complications are necessary.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a diagnosis of probable CNS Malaria, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. He is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and treatment of these complications are necessary to prevent further deterioration and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status, seizures, and anemia. The patient had a generalized seizure lasting 30-45 seconds, which was not treated with ativan, and was loaded with 1000 mg of fosphenytoin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, and blood pressure of 107/48 mmHg. The patient is arousable to voice and follows commands, but has a language barrier. The patient's lungs are clear bilaterally, and the cardiovascular examination is normal.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, and an elevated white blood cell count of 16.3 K/uL. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 24 U/L and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 64 U/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for depression and suicide attempts, as well as a history of domestic abuse.

The patient is currently receiving treatment for malaria, including quinidine and plasma exchange transfusion. The patient is also receiving antibiotics for a possible urinary tract infection, and antiviral therapy for herpes simplex virus (HSV).

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Seizure recurrence: The patient had a seizure yesterday, and the patient's mental status is still altered. The patient may be at risk for another seizure.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of malaria, and the patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count. The patient may be at risk for developing an infection.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be worsening, and the patient may require blood transfusions.
4. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and the patient's mental status is still altered. The patient may be at risk for depression and suicide.
5. Domestic abuse: The patient has a history of domestic abuse, and the patient's mental status is still altered. The patient may be at risk for further abuse.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing treatment for malaria with quinidine and plasma exchange transfusion.
2. Monitoring the patient's mental status and seizure activity.
3. Monitoring the patient's anemia and hemoglobin level.
4. Providing psychological support and counseling for the patient's depression and suicide attempts.
5. Providing social work services to help the patient with domestic abuse issues.
6. Monitoring the patient's language barrier and providing translation services as needed.
7. Following up with the patient's family and friends to ensure that the patient is at their baseline.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female who was recently diagnosed with falciparum malaria and is currently being treated in the ICU. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 107/48 mmHg.

The patient's mental status has improved significantly, and she is now following commands. However, she still has a questionable seizure and remains altered. The patient's EEG and MRI results are pending, but the head CT scan did not show any evidence of bleeding or mass lesions.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL and a hematocrit level of 25.9%. The patient's platelet count is normal, but the white blood cell count is slightly elevated. The patient's liver enzymes are mildly elevated, and the patient has a slightly elevated creatinine level.

The patient's CSF culture results are pending, but the Gram stain and acid-fast culture were negative. The patient's blood and urine cultures are also pending.

The patient's treatment plan includes continued therapy with quinidine, acyclovir, and ceftriaxone. The patient will also receive plasma exchange transfusions to decrease parasitemia. The patient's HIV status is unknown, and the patient is not competent to give consent for testing.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity may be due to cerebral malaria, which can lead to seizures, coma, and even death.
2. Hemolysis: The patient's anemia and elevated bilirubin level may indicate hemolysis, which can be caused by the patient's underlying malaria infection or other factors.
3. Infection: The patient's CSF culture results are pending, and the patient may be at risk for developing an infection, particularly bacterial or fungal meningitis.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is normal, but the patient may be at risk for developing thrombocytopenia, which can lead to bleeding complications.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's quinidine therapy may cause hypoglycemia, which can be life-threatening if not promptly treated.
6. DIC: The patient's elevated creatinine level and slightly elevated INR may indicate disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which can lead to bleeding complications and organ failure.

The patient's treatment plan should be closely monitored and adjusted as necessary to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female from [**Country 1773**] who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and seizures, presumed to be due to probable CNS malaria. She has a history of recent falciparum malaria. The patient was successfully extubated yesterday and had a brief seizure episode, which was treated with phosphenytoin. She is currently receiving empiric acyclovir for possible HSV infection and is being monitored for further seizure activity.

The patient's physical examination is stable, with a normal blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory rate. Her oxygen saturation is 100%, and her SpO2 is 100%. Her neurological examination is also stable, with the patient being attentive, following simple commands, and responding to verbal stimuli.

Laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL. Her white blood cell count is 16.3 K/uL, and her platelet count is 359 K/uL. Her liver function tests are normal, with an ALT level of 24 and an AST level of 26. Her kidney function tests are also normal, with a creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL.

Imaging studies show no focal abnormalities on the MRI head, and the EEG is normal. The patient's parasite smear is pending, and her CSF HSV is also pending.

Potential medical complications:

1. Seizure recurrence: Given the patient's history of seizures, there is a risk of recurrence, especially if her CNS malaria is not adequately treated.
2. Malaria complications: Falciparum malaria can cause a range of complications, including cerebral malaria, respiratory failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if she is not adequately treated with blood transfusions or if she has ongoing bleeding.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, especially given her prolonged hospitalization.
5. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and prior suicidal gestures, which may increase her risk of suicide attempts or self-harm.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and may be at risk of developing nutritional deficiencies if her diet is not adequately advanced.
7. Line-related complications: The patient has multiple lines, including a PICC line and a pheresis catheter, which may increase her risk of line-related complications, such as infection or bleeding.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old female from Country 1773, admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and probable CNS Malaria. The patient has been extubated and is receiving various medications, including fosphenytoin for seizure prophylaxis, acyclovir for empiric treatment of HSV, and quinidine for malaria treatment.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 111/58 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 19 inspirations per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. The patient's neurological examination is normal, with no signs of focal deficit or meningeal irritation.

Laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 10.0 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a slight elevation in creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies, including a MRI head and EEG, are normal. The parasite smear is pending, and the CSF HSV and CX cultures are pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include continued monitoring for seizure activity, empiric treatment for HSV, and treatment for malaria. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to presumed cerebral malaria, and the patient is at risk for further neurological complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Seizure recurrence: The patient has already experienced a seizure, and fosphenytoin has been loaded. Continued monitoring and repeat EEG may be necessary to reassess for seizure activity.
2. Malaria complications: The patient has falciparum malaria, which can lead to severe complications such as cerebral edema, coma, and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
3. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may worsen if not addressed promptly, leading to bleeding complications and increased risk of infection.
4. UTI: The patient has a history of uncomplicated UTI and is at risk for further UTI complications if not properly treated.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and potential seizure activity put her at risk for further neurological complications, including cerebral edema, coma, and death.
6. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to malaria and anemia puts her at risk for secondary infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment plans accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure the best possible outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 57 kg adult admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, fever, and seizure activity. The patient had a PICC line inserted on admission, but it was removed and replaced with a PIV due to the patient pulling it out. The patient has been receiving TPN and quinidine drip, and doxycycline was switched to oral medication. The patient has been diagnosed with hypoactive delirium and is being monitored for depression and suicidal ideation. The patient has a history of seizure activity and is being treated with dilantin, with daily trough levels being monitored. The patient has also been ordered for an L-spine examination for back pain.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 69 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/73 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes an oxygen delivery device, with an SpO2 of 99%. The patient's physical examination is notable for a language barrier, but the patient is arousable and follows commands.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 346 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L and sodium level of 140 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels, particularly potassium and sodium, should be closely monitored to prevent complications such as cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity should be closely monitored, and the dilantin dosage adjusted as necessary to prevent further seizures.
3. Delirium: The patient's delirium should be closely monitored, and the patient should be assessed for depression and suicidal ideation.
4. Infection: The patient's risk of infection is high due to the presence of a central line and the patient's immunocompromised state. The patient's blood and urine cultures should be closely monitored for signs of infection.
5. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is critical, and the patient's fluid status should be closely monitored to prevent complications such as hypervolemia or hypovolemia.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support should be closely monitored, and the patient should be assessed for signs of respiratory failure.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac rhythm should be closely monitored, and the patient should be assessed for signs of cardiac arrhythmias.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a fluid balance of -552 mL, and their respiratory support is minimal, with an O2 delivery device not in use.

The patient has a history of antibiotic use, including ceftriaxone, acyclovir, and doxycycline, and is currently receiving TPN without lipids and quinidine drip. The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count, decreased Hct, and elevated Cr, with pending tests for parasite smear, phenytoin level, and CSF studies.

The patient's physical examination shows arousability to voice, follows commands, and has clear bilateral lungs with no rales or wheezing. The patient's abdomen is soft and nontender with normal bowel sounds, and their extremities are warm with palpable pulses and 5/5 strength.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is -552 mL, which may lead to electrolyte imbalances, particularly hyponatremia or hyperkalemia.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of antibiotic use, and their laboratory results show elevated WBC count, which may indicate an ongoing infection.
3. Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizure activity and altered mental status may lead to further seizure activity, particularly with the introduction of dilantin.
4. Delirium: The patient's history of delirium and altered mental status may lead to further episodes of delirium, particularly with the use of quinidine drip.
5. Malaria: The patient's parasite smear is pending, and their history of travel to areas with malaria may indicate a risk of malaria.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of altered mental status and seizure activity may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly with the use of anticonvulsants.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of altered mental status and seizure activity may lead to respiratory failure, particularly with the use of sedatives and anticonvulsants.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of altered mental status and seizure activity may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, particularly with the use of quinidine drip.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust their fluid balance accordingly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust their antibiotic therapy as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's seizure activity closely and adjust their anticonvulsant therapy as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's delirium and altered mental status closely and adjust their therapy as necessary.
5. Consider further testing for malaria, including PCR, and adjust their treatment accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and adjust their therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust their therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust their therapy as necessary.

   other causes must be considered. Patient had seizure yesterday,

s positive most likely b/c pt received ativan for ?seizure).

s chart. QTc

 if negative, can d/c acyclovir. Also, would

   - Completed 3 days of ceftriaxone for uncomplicated UTI

   West [**Doctor First Name 3223**] per ID recs)

   - Follow parasite smears [**Hospital1 **]
 will check with ID as to when they can

d as they have been negative to date.

 Resolved. Most likely due to malaria.

   - Obtain further records regarding prior malaria treatment and workup

 request faxed [**2184-7-14**] at 1400. Medical Records number in

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female with a recent history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She has undergone plasma exchange transfusion and has received antimalarial treatment. The patient has had a seizure, and an EEG has been performed. The patient's mental status has improved, but she is still confused and disoriented. The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and is also a victim of domestic abuse.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity suggest that cerebral malaria may be a possibility. Further monitoring and treatment with antimalarial medication are necessary to manage this condition.
2. Post-ictal state: The patient's confusion and disorientation may be due to a post-ictal state, which is a common complication of seizures. Close monitoring and observation are necessary to ensure that the patient's mental status improves.
3. Non-convulsive status: The patient's altered mental status may also be due to non-convulsive status, which is a condition characterized by altered mental status without seizure activity. EEG monitoring is necessary to rule out this condition.
4. Meningitis: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity may also be due to meningitis, which is a common complication of malaria. Lumbar puncture and CSF studies are necessary to rule out this condition.
5. Depression: The patient's history of depression and suicide attempts makes it necessary to monitor her mental status closely and provide appropriate treatment and support.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to the underlying malaria infection or to other factors such as hemolysis or bleeding. Close monitoring of her hemoglobin levels and treatment with blood transfusions if necessary are necessary.
7. QT prolongation: The patient's quinidine therapy may cause QT prolongation, which is a potential complication of this medication. Close monitoring of her electrocardiogram and treatment with medications to prevent QT prolongation if necessary are necessary.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's quinidine therapy may also cause hypoglycemia, which is a potential complication of this medication. Close monitoring of her blood glucose levels and treatment with medications to prevent hypoglycemia if necessary are necessary.

The patient's mental status has improved significantly from admission, and she is now following commands. The patient had a seizure on day 2 of admission, and an EEG was performed yesterday with results indicating no focal deficits.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Seizure activity: The patient had a seizure on day 2 of admission, and the EEG indicates ongoing seizure activity. The patient is being treated with Dilantin for seizure prophylaxis.
2. Hypoactive delirium: The patient is experiencing delirium, which is likely related to her altered mental status.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely related to her hemolytic anemia from malaria.
4. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and is at risk for depression given her current situation.
5. Malnutrition: The patient is malnourished, as evidenced by her low albumin levels and need for supplemental nutrition.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of malaria, and is at risk for further infection given her compromised immune system.
7. Neurological complications: The patient is at risk for neurological complications, including cerebral malaria, which can lead to permanent neurological damage.

The patient is being treated with quinidine for her malaria, and will likely have her IV quinidine stopped soon. * PICC line removal and replacement with a PIV catheter

* Start of dilantin 100mg TID for seizure prophylaxis
* Neuroimaging not performed due to psychomotor slowing without focal deficits
* Continuous 24-hour EEG monitoring
* Consultation with psychiatry for hypoactive delirium, with plans to follow up with resources for depression and substance abuse once delirium clears

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 69 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/73 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 99% and no respiratory distress.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count of 12.9 K/uL
* Hct of 23.5%
* Plt of 346 K/uL
* Cr of 0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose of 126 mg/dL

The patient has a pending CSF study for Lyme, EEE, West Nile, CMV, and HSV.

The patient is at risk for:

* Electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Airway compromise due to inability to protect airway
* Malaria
* DVT and stress ulcer prophylaxis
* VAP

The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is to call out in the morning once the quinidine drip is discontinued.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Seizure activity due to dilantin toxicity or underlying seizure disorder
* Respiratory compromise due to airway compromise or aspiration
* Electrolyte and fluid disorders due to TPN and quinidine drip
* Malaria due to lack of treatment
* DVT and stress ulcer prophylaxis due to immobility and risk factors
* VAP due to prolonged intubation and risk factors.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female with a recent history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She was admitted to the ICU and received plasma exchange transfusion on the day of admission to decrease parasitemia. Her mental status has improved, and she is now following commands. However, other causes of her altered mental status must be considered, including seizure activity, non-convulsive status, and potential infection.

The patient has had a seizure in the past and was treated with ativan, which may have contributed to her current confusional state. She also has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and is a victim of domestic abuse.

The patient's lab results show anemia, with a baseline Hct uncertain. Her coagulation studies are normal, making DIC less likely. Her electrolyte levels are normal, and her glucose level is slightly elevated.

The patient is being treated with IV quinidine for one more day, and will have her parasite smears checked daily. She will also have her blood, urine, and CSF studies sent for cultures and HSV PCR. Her HIV status is unknown, but she is negative for HIV according to her friends.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure activity: The patient has had a seizure in the past and may be at risk for another seizure. Continuous EEG monitoring may be necessary to monitor her seizure activity.
2. Infection: The patient's altered mental status may be due to an underlying infection, such as bacterial meningitis or TB meningitis. Further evaluation is necessary to rule out these possibilities.
3. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and may be at risk for depression during her hospitalization.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to hemolysis or another underlying condition. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the cause of her anemia.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient is at risk for hypoglycemia due to her quinidine treatment. She will need to have her glucose levels monitored regularly.
6. QT prolongation: The patient's quinidine treatment may cause QT prolongation, which can increase her risk for cardiac arrhythmias. Her EKG will need to be monitored regularly.
7. Malaria relapse: The patient's malaria treatment may not be effective in eradicating the parasite, and she may be at risk for relapse. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the effectiveness of her treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue IV quinidine for one more day, and monitor the patient's seizure activity and mental status.
2. Send blood, urine, and CSF studies for cultures and HSV PCR to rule out underlying infections.
3. Monitor the patient's glucose levels regularly to prevent hypoglycemia.
4. Monitor the patient's EKG regularly to prevent QT prolongation.
5. Consider antidepressant treatment to manage the patient's depression.
6. Consider social work consultation to address the patient's depression and domestic abuse history.
7. Consider HIV testing once the patient is able to give consent.

The patient's condition has improved, but she remains hypoactive/apathetic and is likely experiencing depression or possible delirium.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Malaria: Falciparum malaria can lead to severe complications, including cerebral malaria, if left untreated or inadequately treated.
2. Seizures: The patient has had a seizure, which may be a result of CSF infection or malaria. Phosphenytoin has been loaded, and dilantin is being started. Continuous EEG monitoring is planned to ensure seizure control.
3. UTI: The patient has been treated for an uncomplicated UTI, but further monitoring is necessary to prevent complications.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is attributed to malaria, and it is essential to monitor her hemoglobin levels and treat any underlying causes.
5. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and has experienced suicidal gestures. Social work consultation and psychiatric evaluation are necessary to address her mental health needs.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving TPN without lipids, which may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not monitored and adjusted accordingly.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, including DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP, which need to be prophylactically treated and monitored.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizures may indicate neurological complications, which require close monitoring and further evaluation.

Given the patient's condition, it is essential to continue monitoring her neurological status, treating her malaria, and addressing her mental health needs. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent and manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female from [**Country 1773**] who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and seizures, likely due to cerebral malaria. She has a history of recent falciparum malaria and was started on dilantin for seizure prophylaxis. Her current vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 105/69 mmHg. She is tolerating oral medications and has a patent IV line. Her laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.4 g/dL, and elevated liver enzymes. She has also been diagnosed with depression and has a history of suicidal gestures.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Malaria: The patient's condition is still complicated by falciparum malaria, which can lead to severe complications such as cerebral edema, seizures, and respiratory failure if not properly treated.
2. Seizures: The patient's seizure activity may continue or worsen if not properly managed with anticonvulsant therapy.
3. Depression: The patient's depression and suicidal tendencies may worsen if not properly managed with psychotherapy and medication.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly treated with blood transfusions and iron supplements.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections due to her compromised immune system.
6. Neurological complications: The patient may develop neurological complications such as cerebral edema, seizures, and stroke due to her cerebral malaria.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient may develop cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias, hypertension, and cardiac failure due to her anemia and compromised cardiovascular system.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and seizure activity closely.
2. Continue anticonvulsant therapy and adjust as needed.
3. Continue depression therapy and adjust as needed.
4. Continue anemia treatment with blood transfusions and iron supplements.
5. Monitor for signs of infection and treat promptly if necessary.
6. Monitor for signs of neurological complications and treat promptly if necessary.
7. Monitor for signs of cardiovascular complications and treat promptly if necessary.
8. Consider transfer to a higher level of care if the patient's condition worsens.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female with a recent history of falciparum malaria, presenting with altered mental status. She received plasma exchange transfusion on admission to decrease parasitemia, and her last smear was negative. However, she had a seizure on day 2, and her current confusional state may be due to post-ictal status or nonconvulsive status. She is currently on IV quinidine, which is pending ID recs to stop, and is also receiving anticonvulsant medication. Her fever has resolved, and she is being followed up with pending CSF studies, blood and urine cultures.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cerebral malaria: The patient's altered mental status and seizure may be due to cerebral malaria, which can lead to severe neurological complications if not treated promptly.
2. Post-ictal status: The patient's current confusional state may be due to post-ictal status, which can lead to prolonged confusion and disorientation.
3. Nonconvulsive status: The patient's current confusional state may also be due to nonconvulsive status, which can lead to prolonged confusion and disorientation.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient is at risk of hypoglycemia due to quinidine therapy, which can lead to seizures, coma, and even death if not treated promptly.
5. QT prolongation: The patient is at risk of QT prolongation on quinidine therapy, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death if not monitored closely.
6. Infection: The patient's immune system may be compromised due to malaria and other underlying medical conditions, making her susceptible to infections.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing hemolysis or other underlying medical conditions.
8. Depression: The patient has a history of depression and suicide attempts, and may be at risk of worsening depression or even suicide if not properly managed.
9. Domestic abuse: The patient is a victim of domestic abuse, and may be at risk of further harm or exploitation if not properly protected.

Recommendations:

1. Continue IV quinidine pending ID recs to stop.
2. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and treat hypoglycemia promptly if it occurs.
3. Monitor the patient's EKG daily to evaluate for QT prolongation on quinidine therapy.
4. Continue anticonvulsant medication and monitor the patient's seizure activity.
5. Follow up with pending CSF studies, blood and urine cultures to rule out other underlying infections.
6. Consider consulting a psychiatrist to manage the patient's depression and provide counseling on domestic abuse.
7. Ensure the patient's safety by screening visitors and monitoring her activity level.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and hemolysis, and consider consulting a hematologist if necessary.

Summary:

The patient, a 24-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and a history of falciparum malaria. She has undergone plasma exchange transfusion and received quinidine therapy. Her mental status has improved, and she is now following commands. However, she still requires close monitoring and treatment for potential complications.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 11.8-10.5 K/uL
* Hct: 25.0-25.9%
* Plt: 299-450 K/uL
* Cr: 0.5-0.6 mg/dL
* Glucose: 101-126 mg/dL
* Phenytoin level: 10.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes:

* Recent falciparum malaria
* History of depression and suicide attempts
* Victim of domestic abuse

The patient's current medications include:

* Quinidine drip
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Phenytoin
* Acyclovir (discontinued)
* Ceftriaxone (discontinued)

Potential medical complications:

* Cerebral malaria
* Post-ictal status or nonconvulsive status
* Bacterial meningitis or TB meningitis
* Hypoglycemia due to quinidine
* DIC due to hemolysis
* Nutritional deficiencies
* Seizure precautions
* Domestic abuse

Assessment and Plan:

* Continue IV quinidine pending ID recs
* Discontinue acyclovir
* Complete 3 days of ceftriaxone for uncomplicated UTI
* Follow-up blood, urine, and CSF studies
* EKG to evaluate for QT prolongation on quinidine
* Follow fingerstick q4h as quinidine can cause hypoglycemia
* Follow parasite smears
* HIV status once patient able to give consent
* Seizure precautions
* Plan for 24-hour EEG soon per neuro
* Started Dilantin for seizures
* Monitor po intake and see if patient needs more supplemental nutrition
* Change from bedrest to activity with assistance and monitor for ataxia
* Consult with psych and social work for depression and domestic abuse

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: Advanced to regular diet with nutrition consult for calorie count
* Glycemic control: Monitor glucose levels and adjust therapy as necessary
* Lines: Monitor for signs of infection or bleeding
* Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots and heparin sq for DVT, stress ulcer prophylaxis not indicated, VAP prophylaxis not necessary.
